video.title: Git for Professionals Tutorial - Tools & Concepts for Mastering Version Control with Git
video.description:
Git has the power to make you a better software developer. But you'll have to go beyond the basic "commit, push, pull" to use it effectively! In this course, we'll look at some of the more advanced concepts and tools to make you more productive and confident with Git.

This course focuses on using Git with the command line.

✏️ This course was created by Tobias Günther from Tower. You can download Tower's Git desktop UI here: https://www.git-tower.com

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:52) Hosted by Tower
⌨️ (01:27) The perfect commit
⌨️ (08:07) Branching strategies
⌨️ (17:16) Pull requests
⌨️ (24:07) Merge conflicts
⌨️ (33:48) Merge vs. rebase
⌨️ (40:05) The Advanced Git Kit: https://www.git-tower.com/learn/git/advanced-git-kit/

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Tal Kohavy
topLevelComment.text:
I consider myself as pretty profficiant with git,
yet I'm doing this thing where i'm occasionally revisiting known technologies to maybe learn some new things.
Anyhow, just I wanted to say that this 40-minutes long video was ALL WORTH IT just for the sake of learning about the git add with the -p flag to only mark some parts of a file to be included in the commit :) Love it! definitely gonna use it in the future♥ Thank you!

replies.author: Tal Kohavy
replies.text: @シムカ Plus, it doesn't work very well. Since posting this comment I tried using it, and man it sucks... sometimes it takes 2 or 3 rows and considers them as ONE CHANGE! Take it or leave it! When in fact each row is a chance on it's own, where I want only one of them. And yeah, the point you made is also valid. Haven't used it since. But it's nice to know all these "secret" git command. like git rerere for instance 😉

replies.author: シムカ
replies.text: this is an introductory video, and "-p" flag is useless. As in the real work, most ppl uses temporary local branch with a logical name for each commit, thus no need to deal with staging or splitting commits especially in case of 50+ modified files.

replies.author: maweibezahn
replies.text: @Toby imprint.html is often the name of the file that contains the contact information. This section of the site is considered the "Impressum" in Germany and is legally required in many cases (e.g. commercial sites). "Impressum" is often translated to "imprint" by Germans, but this is a false friend. A more suitable name would be "Legal Info" or something similar.

topLevelComment.author: Siddharth Sharma
topLevelComment.text:
Great video,
However I see at time 34:44 (and many other times too), there are 2 arrows. One shows where branch is progressing. The other one points in other direction i.e. the directionwhere branch started(on c3 -> c2 -> c1). (the opposite arrow is orange in color)

Why is one arrow opposite from other? Whats the purpose?

Again thank you for the great content. Cleared up so many things for me

replies.author: Siddharth Sharma
replies.text:
So I have learned a bit more about git, the arrows are a good tracking tool. So for example, say you make a commit, you can follow the arrows to see what past commits this new commit is built upon. 

Say you have a commit and you can trace all the arrows from that commit to any other commit, if you can cover all the paths following arrows, you can be sure that this new commit has all the previous commit history.

The purpose of the arrow is to 
1. Find parent commit 
2. More generally follow commit path

If bugs are reported soon, developer still know what he was doing and bug fix can be quick.

topLevelComment.author: Всеслав Полоцкий
topLevelComment.text: Taking into account the video name "Git for Professionals..." (professional housekeepers?) rebase explanation is quite fluffy and misleading. What really happens when you do the 'git rebase branch_b' from branch_a is that that commit history on branch_b left untouched (nothing is moved to branch_b, as the branch is just a pointer), and just unique commits from branch_b are applied one-by-one (cherry-picked) to branch_a and the branch_a pointer moved to the last applied commit.

topLevelComment.author: marcello42
topLevelComment.text:
What are you doing to avoid following scenario - I am not sure how often this happens, but I think this could occur quite often:

Person A changes a file - let's say a parameter in a function, which was perhaps a bug
Person B works on a different branch, tests it's new feature wasn't aware that there is a change in a function he used..

both gets merged into dev - no conflicts obviously..

Are dev branches freezed usually to be tested completely before merging into main and at a certain point there are done only tests without any further merges into dev to avoid this situation?

And is someone who works on a different branch constantly pulling changes from the current (dev) branch?
Especially this is in my interest how people are dealing with this.

replies.author: Toby
replies.text: All final testing should be performed on the release branch in my opinion (whichever that is). Git typically complicates things by there being extra branches hanging around (feature branches) and them getting out of date causing unnecessary conflicts.

topLevelComment.author: Stephan Hoyer
topLevelComment.text: For me the most important thing that belongs in a commit message is: Why this change. This should go in the subject not the What, because the What can be seen easily by looking at the changes. I think commit-messages as annotations to the changed lines, not describing the history of the project. So I write the messages for `git blame` and not for `git log`

topLevelComment.author: Hasan Ali
topLevelComment.text:
notes to self:
only combine changes of a single topic in the same commit,
git add -p  enables staging parts of the changes of a file (patch level), of course, the file must already be tracked (using git add).
merge: combining two different branches, it creates a merge commit in the process. with merge the two branches keep there own history seperated:
b1-------- c1---------c2-----------------cm
        b2    |----c1-----c2--- c3 -------|
rebase: rebase will unite the two commit histories of both branches, do not use rebase changes pushed to remote repo, rebase diagram:
           before rebase:
           b1:  c1-------------c3------------
           b2    |-------c2-----------c4-----
           after rebase:
           c1-----c2-----c4-----c3*
notice that c3 is at the end, rebase moves commits that happened on b1 after the common ancestor, this means that c3 has changed (different parent)

topLevelComment.author: Perry van den Hondel
topLevelComment.text: A small remark; please clarify. Seems to me that the arrows are placed in the opposite direction of the development flow. Should I read them as a change is pulled from a previous step?  I presume the diagrams need to be read from from left to right but the arrows seem to point against this direction.

replies.author: JM
replies.text: @Californ1a Thanks for clarifying this; it was somehow strange to see the newer commits at the right, but the arrows pointing to the opposite direction. Now it makes sense.

replies.author: Adel Imamovic
replies.text: Are you referring to the red arrows e.g. at https://youtu.be/Uszj_k0DGsg?t=949? Every commit is a knot in a directed acyclic graph and refers to a previous commit.

replies.author: Californ1a
replies.text: The arrows point to the parent of the commit, whatever previous commit that one references since that's how git tracks history, using a reference to the previous commit. He's showing how git "looks back" through that history, and follows those references backward to find the common ancestor.

And about branch-strategy, I would prefer short-live branches. 

I love Pull Requests, you can even undo the whole pull request if needed. Even if there are a lot of commits. You only have to revert the pull request. Thats great.

topLevelComment.author: David Clark
topLevelComment.text: Good content.  However, I think you missed one of the more common patterns involving rebase and merge.  In your case of an LT branchA and work branchB with changes on both you rebased the changes in branchA on the changes in branchB.   In my experience, it is more common to rebase the changes in branchB on the changes in branchA (checkout branchB, rebase branchA, <resolve conflicts, build, test>, commit) then merge the resolved changes back into branchA (checkout branchA, merge branchB).  That final merge MUST be a fast-forward.  If it isn't, start over.  This completely avoids the problem of rewriting history on branchA that you alluded to.  Given branchA may be used as a base by other developers and could be hosted on a server that disallows history changes, that is essential.

topLevelComment.text:
You should never rebase on a branch that someone else could work on, but if you're the only one working on a branch then it's safe to rebase and force-push new history.
I do it quite often so that you can break down the changes in a PR by commit.

replies.author: Adam Spiers
replies.text: Incorrect, many Open Source projects require rebasing of PR branches, and there are many good reasons for this. Your advice could be more accurately rephrased as "never rebase a shared branch without making sure that there is a clear expectation that this can happen".

topLevelComment.author: Ethan Neff
topLevelComment.text: This is way too complex. Ban long running branches. Force squash merge on pull requests. Require all pull requests to be updated to date with master. Keep the process simple. Anything else is just organizing waste with the illusion of being productive. The most productive thing an engineer can do is ship production code. Make your processes prioritize that.

Version control used to be simple, something you never really had to think about.

replies.author: Jim Morrison
replies.text: @Vorrnth I know Git very well. I have been using it for years. Yes, it doesn't need to be complex, but the problem is that it is too easy to abuse. People love overcomplicating solutions, and Git allows this too much. You ask a question about Git to a team people of people, and you will get ten different answers. Maybe five of them will work, and five of them won't. Anyway, thanks for your reply.

replies.author: Gregory Stocker
replies.text: @Nick Schmitt Right, to squash your own individual local commits together. I meant it’s usually not advised to rebase a collaboration branch. Or at least that’s how I was taught to best avoid merge conflicts due to separate histories etc..

replies.author: Nick Schmitt
replies.text: @Gregory Stocker No, it's common for individual team members to rebase their local commits before pushing to remote.

replies.author: Andrej Marinić
replies.text: the answer to the question of "when should I use rebase?" is "never." rebase promises to "keep the history clean", whereas I would say it does exactly the opposite. for me, a clean history is one that shows everything, the good and the bad. rebase erases the bad if things go well, or erases the good, if things go bad. there's nothing clean about that, just lies. dirty lies I say!!!

replies.author: Gregory Stocker
replies.text:
Rebase is usually discouraged when collaborating with others because because it rearranges your history and can really mess things up. 

It’s usually better to add to an existing code base with a new merge commit than to scramble what was there before to fit your new change linearly. 

Rebase is good for when you want a single, linear history for yourself and don’t care about losing a true path for how things evolved. 

Performing merges that are considered “fast forwards” is key when collaborating with others using a shared dev branch and ensures no merge conflicts.
